journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Energy optimal trajectory planning of an underwater robot using a genetic algorithm

contrib-group.aff: Robotics and Control Laboratory, Indian Institute of Technology, India

author-notes.corresp: Pushparaj M Pathak, Robotics and Control Laboratory, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee 247667, India. Email: pushpfme@iitr.ernet.in

abstract.p: This paper presents optimal trajectory planning for an autonomous underwater robot. The optimization parameter is taken as the energy consumed by the robot to traverse its arm tip from a predefined initial point to a final point. The bond graph technique is used for modeling the robot and a genetic algorithm is used as an optimization tool. A polynomial trajectory is considered so that the tip movement is smooth. SYMBOLS Shakti¯ is used as bond graph modeling software and its special feature of generation of CPP code containing the robot model’s expressions is used. The genetic algorithm is implemented on the generated CPP code. Simulation and results for an energy efficient trajectory are presented.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Oceans are home to a huge amount of wealth comprising petroleum, gas reserves, gems and biological rarities. This wealth lies in underwater environs that are very hostile to humans. To overcome this difficulty, underwater vehicle-based robots are widely used for maintenance, inspection, oil exploration and pipe laying in the offshore petroleum industries. Such robots have applications in deep sea salvage expeditions, geological, biological and gemological explorations, submarines and construction. Many of these applications require repetitive motion of the robot arm. Energy supply can be considered unlimited in the case of remotely operated vehicles, but such vehicles have limitations in distance covered and their movement is severely hampered by tether drag. Also the weight of the tether adds to energy consumption. Optimization of the trajectory followed by the arm tip carries significance as the underwater environment restricts the generation of energy through solar panels and energy storage is also limited because of weight constraints. There are many ways in which energy can be conserved in the case of underwater robots, but energy conservation carries more weight in all of them.

Dixit1 explained the bond graph modeling of a three-degree-of-freedom (3-DOF) underwater robot. He modeled the gravitational forces and hydrodynamic forces such as buoyancy, drag and added mass effects. Pathak2 explained the arm and vehicle dynamics of a space robot. The modeling of an underwater robot is similar to that of a space robot as both have a floating base. Ridao et al.3 presented the complete three-dimensional (3D) kinematics and a dynamics matrix-based model. This model uses the dynamics equations which describe the movement of a rigid body and the main hydrodynamic equations affecting this movement through a fluid environment. Schjølberg and Fossen4 derived the dynamic model of an underwater vehicle manipulator system. The iterative Newton–Euler algorithm was extended to include the most dominating hydrodynamic forces. Tian and Collins5 presented a trajectory planning method for a robot manipulator whose workspace includes several obstacles by using a genetic algorithm (GA). Garg and Kumar6 presented the formulation and application of a strategy for determination of an optimal trajectory for a multiple robotic configuration using GA and simulated annealing as the optimization techniques. Capi et al.7 presented a prismatic joint biped robot trajectory planning method. The minimum torque change cost function and constant vertical position trajectories were used to compare the results. Hein and Meystel8 developed a genetic programming technique that finds admissible control strategies that tend to minimize the robotic vehicle’s time through the obstacle field. However these studies are confined to simple manipulator cases. Luo et al.9 presented integrated optimization of trajectory planning for robot manipulators. The method is based on intensified evolutionary programming. Sakagami and Kawamura10 presented a new time optimal control method without parameter estimation. The proposed method is based on iterative learning control and time-scale transformation. Zhang11 proposed a hierarchical global path planning approach for an autonomous underwater vehicle in the ocean. This approach consists of successive decomposition of the robot’s workspace and searching for a path at each level of decomposition. To get the global shortest path, a GA was used for its efficient optimization. Cheng et al.12 proposed a path planner combining a GA with dynamic programming to solve the path planning problem of autonomous underwater vehicles.

The present paper concerns optimization of the trajectory for a 3-DOF underwater robot using bond graph modeling and a GA. The bond graph is used for modeling the underwater robot and developing the trajectory control strategy, while the GA is used because of its robustness and acceptable accuracy with quickness in finding solutions. A polynomial trajectory is considered to illustrate the methodology. The contribution of the work is the integration of the two methods in deriving the optimal trajectory.

sec.title: Model of the three-dgeree-of-freedom underwater robot
sec.p: Underwater robotic systems comprise two peculiar components: the manipulator and the base or vehicle. As the manipulator end-effector traverses the desired path for a specific application, all forces and torques are transferred from the end-effector to the base. In the present work the base of the robot and the links of the arm are considered to be cylindrical. The configuration of the robot is taken as RRR (all rotating joints). The coordinate frames assigned and used for the notation are shown in Figure 1. The dynamic model of the rigid underwater body is given by4

where F, τ are external input forces and torques matrix, respectively; (M+MA)ij is the mass and added mass matrices; (C+CA)ij is the Coriolis and centripetal matrices;

caption.p: Schematic representation of the 3-DOF underwater manipulator vehicle.1

sec.p: There are many hydrodynamic forces acting on the robot such as ocean currents, waves, wind, hydrodynamic damping, and restoring forces by gravity and buoyancy. These forces are modeled using certain assumptions. The body is moving below the ocean surface at a depth of 30 m, so the effect of waves can be neglected. Wind effects are not considered as the body is fully submerged in water. For the development of the equations in this section it is further assumed that the fluid is irrotational, still and unbounded.

Bond graph modeling of the underwater robot is modular in structure, i.e. it uses basic building blocks and they are used repetitively to simulate the base, arms and linkages. Linear dynamics of the vehicle, angular dynamics of the vehicle and arm linear and angular dynamics equations are used to construct the sub-models. These sub-models are assembled to create the bond graph model of the underwater robot.

sec.title: Gravity and buoyancy forces and torques
sec.p: The resultant of gravity and buoyancy forces is acting on the CG of the respective link and vehicle. As all of the forces are expressed in the inertial frame of reference, the resultant of gravity and buoyancy can be directly added at “1x” junction of the linear dynamics as shown in Figure 2. Expression of the torque about the joint axis due to the resultant of gravity and buoyancy forces is given by

sec.title: Hydrodynamic damping forces and torques
sec.p: There are two significant hydrodynamic damping forces:4 quadratic drag (i.e. vortex shedding) and linear skin friction. Although in general the damping of an underwater vehicle at high speed will be highly nonlinear and coupled, certain assumptions are made to simplify the analysis. The most common simplification is that the linear and quadratic damping forces resolved in a particular axis depend on the component of the velocity vector in that axis. It is assumed that the vehicle has symmetry about the principal frame, hence it performs non-coupled motion. Higher than second-order hydrodynamic damping coefficients are considered to be negligible, so the hydrodynamic damping force matrix D contains only linear and quadratic damping force terms. Velocity of the rigid body relative to the flow has to be considered while calculating the damping forces. As we have assumed already that the fluid is still, we can use the velocity of the body as the relative velocity to flow. Expression of the linear damping force in the x direction of the body frame is given by

where “V” is the velocity component of the link in one of the three directions and Cfl is the coefficient of friction for linear damping. On the same lines we can write the damping forces in the y and z directions as
From equations (14) and (15) we can write the linear hydrodynamic damping force matrix as
Similarly the linear hydrodynamic damping torque matrix is given as
where ωx, ωy and ωz are the angular velocities of the body. The quadratic damping force is given by Morison’s equation as
where a is the projected cross-sectional area and Cd is the coefficient of drag for quadratic damping. Cd is a function of the Reynold’s number Re, which is given as

where L is the characteristic length and µ is the kinematic viscosity of water. Cd is considered as 1 for subcritical flow, i.e. Re<2000. If subscripts to the coefficients of drag show the coefficient along the respective direction, the quadratic damping force matrix is given as
On the same lines, the quadratic hydrodynamic damping torque matrix is given as

Hydrodynamic damping forces are modeled by attaching R elements at force-summing “1” junctions of the linear dynamics as shown in Figure 2. The modulus of the R element is the summation of hydrodynamic damping coefficients for linear and quadratic damping. Hydrodynamic damping torques are modeled by attaching R elements at torque-summing “1” junctions of the angular dynamics.

sec.title: Added mass forces
sec.p: The fluid kinetic energy principle states that motion of the body will induce motion of the fluid particles. In order to allow the body to pass through the fluid, the fluid passage possesses kinetic energy that it would lack if the body was not in motion.3 The reaction experienced by the body is called “the added mass effect”.
The equations of added mass forces and torques are given by Schjølberg and Fossen4 as

If the vehicle has symmetry about the principal frame, the contribution from the off-diagonal added mass elements can be neglected. The diagonal structure is highly attractive since off-diagonal elements are difficult to determine from either experiments or theory.3 Expressions for the added mass matrix and added inertia matrix for a symmetrical body are given as

where

are called “added mass coefficients”. Added mass coefficients are coefficients that can be directly added to the mass and inertia terms of body acceleration forces. Schjølberg and Fossen4 have given a detailed procedure to derive these added mass coefficients. For slender bodies, an estimate of the added mass coefficients can be obtained by applying strip theory.

For cylindrical bodies the added mass coefficients

Added mass components are added in the modulus of I elements of the linear dynamics as shown in Figure 2. Similarly, added inertia components are added in I elements of the EJS.

sec.title: Integrated model description
sec.p: The sub-models of the junction structure of angular velocity propagation, linear velocity propagation of the link and EJS are repeatedly used for all links in the manipulator chain. The integrated bond graph is shown in Figure 2. In Figure 2, “AD of link” represents a sub-model for the angular velocity propagation of links. This sub-model takes the angular velocity of the previous link and the joint velocity as input and the angular velocity of the current link is given out after calculation. “LD of link” represents a sub-model for linear velocity propagation of links. The “LD of link” sub-model takes the angular velocity of the current link and the tip velocity of the previous link as input and gives the velocity of the CG of the current link and tip velocity of the current link as output. The angular velocity to Euler angle rate sub-model is used to convert the angular velocity to Euler angle rates as output. Various forces such as gravity, buoyancy and hydrodynamic forces are modeled. “ROW” represents the robust overwhelming13 trajectory controller. This sub-model takes the vehicle angular velocity, the linear velocity of the robot base and the joint angular velocity as input. The tip velocity, which is provided to the robust overwhelming controller sub-model, is compared with the flow command and the error in flow is sent to the overwhelming controller. The overwhelming controller returns the correction effort.

sec.title: Simulation and results
sec.p: To see the efficacy of the modeling and control scheme, the physical parameters were set as shown in Table 1. The initial robot configuration used in the simulation is shown in Figure 3. The reference velocity commands of the manipulator tip in the absolute frame are taken as

caption.p: Initial configuration of the underwater robot.
Initial configuration of the underwater robot.

sec.p: This is a circular trajectory in the YZ plane and a parabolic trajectory in the XY and XZ planes and R is the radius of the reference circle in the YZ plane. Simulation results (Figure 4) show that the trajectory controller controls the trajectory of the underwater robot for a certain time until the vehicle does not move out of its reachable workspace. This provides the base for the optimization of trajectory planning using a GA. The bond graph model provides the information about the power required by the joint motors to traverse the reference trajectory. This information is further used to optimize the trajectory traversed by the manipulator tip to move from a predefined initial point to a final point.

sec.title: Optimization using genetic algorithm
sec.p: Bond graphs and GAs14 are both emerging as promising techniques in the field of modeling and optimization, respectively. That is why amalgamation of both techniques can be used to solve many problems. The basic requirement of a GA is that the objective function be formulated properly. In the case of robots the mathematical model can form the objective function, giving us options to optimize various attributes such as energy, time and jerk. In the present case, the mathematical model is obtained in single scalar closed form using the bond graph. The bond graph modeling software SYMBOLS Shakti¯ is used for modeling purposes.15 The mathematical model is automatically generated in the form of a CPP code. This CPP code contains state equations as well as user-defined equations.

The state equations yield time derivatives of states which need to be integrated with respect to time for obtaining the values of states for the next time step. The Runge–Kutta–Felhberg (RKF45) ordinary differential equation solver with adaptive step size control is used as numerical integrator.

User equations are user-defined equations for desired output. In our case, we want to calculate the energy required by the joint motors to move the arm tip from an initial point to a final point. Thus the user equations defined are
and

where P1, P2 and P3 are the powers required by the motors at the first, second and third joints respectively and T1, T2 and T3 are the torques required by the three joint motors. Thus, after the numerical integration of time derivatives of states, we finally get the torque and power required by the robot to traverse the trajectory. This then becomes the objective function which is to be optimized using the GA.
In the present work, a real coded simple GA has been used. The features of the GA are as follows.

list-item.p: It is a real coded simple GA. The meaning of “real coded” is that the variables are taken as real numbers and are not converted into binary form.
Simulated binary crossover is used as crossover strategy.
For reproduction, tournament selection is used.
Polynomial mutation strategy is used, as this is a case of a real coded GA.

sec.p: Figure 5 shows the flowchart used for implementation of the GA. A genetic program (CPP) was created to find the optimal trajectory. The objective function of the genetic program is the energy required by the robot arm to traverse from a predefined initial point to a final point. The results were obtained for the coefficients of minimum energy consuming trajectory.
We have considered the case of a 3-DOF underwater robot having a trajectory controller. The robot has to perform the task of moving its arm tip from a predefined initial point to a final point.

sec.title: Trajectory of arm tip
sec.p: A polynomial trajectory is chosen so that movement of the arm is jerk-free. The trajectory in x, y and z directions is chosen to be
So the velocity input derived by differentiating the workspace trajectory input is

where Vx, Vy and Vz are the velocities of the tip in the x, y and z directions. The initial and final tip positions assumed are shown in Table 2 and also represented by Figure 6(a) and (b). The initial and final velocity of the tip in all directions is considered as zero.

caption.p: Coordinates of initial and final points.
Initial and final configuration of the robot: (a) initial position of the robot tip; (b) a possible configuration for final position of the robot tip.

sec.p: First of all a relationship between the coefficients of the polynomial is established using the initial and final conditions so that change in only one coefficient will effect a change in all coefficients of the polynomial.
Consider a polynomial trajectory in the x direction
The velocity expression will be given by
Let the initial and final x coordinates of the trajectory at the final time tf be x0 and xf, and let the initial velocity and final velocity be v0 and vf. Then the using initial conditions we get
Substituting the final conditions, we get
From equations (28) and (29), we get
Solving equations (30) and (31) yields
If we assume 1, 2 and 3 as suffixes for x, y and z directions, the velocity expressions in x, y and z directions can be expressed as follows.

Thus the only input variable that remains is the value of C1, C2 and C3. Thus by varying the value of C1, C2 and C3 we can get different polynomial trajectories.

sec.title: Simulation and results
sec.p: Table 3 shows the inputs required for the genetic program. Here, a number of generations is taken to meet the convergence criterion. A high crossover probability and low mutation probability are used to avoid any loss of important data from the population of trajectories. The results obtained for one run of the genetic program are shown in Table 4. The coefficients of the optimal trajectory obtained, the average power required by the robot to traverse the trajectory and the total energy required, calculated by multiplying the average power and the time required to traverse the trajectory, are tabulated. Analysis of the results shows the decrease in total energy required by the robot in successive generations. The last few entries of total energy and average power in Table 4 show the convergence reached by the GA. Thus from Table 4, we can conclude that the average power and energy required by the trajectory defined in generations 10 and 11 are least among all, respectively. The plot of the trajectory is shown in Figure 7.

tr.th: Coefficients of optimal trajectory obtained from GA (C1, C2, C3)

sec.p: The power consumed by the robot during trajectory tracking is shown in Figure 8. We can see from the power plot that the power required initially by the robot increases rapidly. One reason for that is the sudden requirement of power by the joint motors to actuate the joints for movement of the arm against the drag forces.

caption.p: Power variation for the optimal trajectory traveled by the robot tip.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present paper shows the results of integration of a GA and a bond graph for obtaining the energy optimal trajectory of a 3-DOF underwater robot. The bond graph is used for generation of system equations and design of the controller, while the GA is used for finding the trajectory which consumes minimum power. Convergence of the genetic program is achieved within a small number of generations. Experimental validation of the results needs to be done. In the present model of the underwater robot, only a trajectory controller is incorporated which takes care of disturbances until the trajectory does not reach out of the workspace of the robot. Improvement in the model can be done with the incorporation of an attitude controller to take care of the gravitational forces and vehicle rotations due to various forces.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
